data.title: Lil Wayne, Travis Barker, and the Pop Punk Resurgence
data.meta_description: Back in the early 2000s, when I was in high school, pop punk and emo were the rock music of the time. Blink-182 had reached the top and then broke up during the aughts. But before they left the…
data.text:
Back in the early 2000s, when I was in high school, pop punk and emo were the rock music of the time. Blink-182 had reached the top and then broke up during the aughts. But before they left the scene, they stamped their mark on young artists who would enter into a music career to follow in their footsteps.

Like most trends, the genre of pop punk has been revitalized and re-popularized with a modern twist, largely because of what Mark Hoppus, Tom DeLonge, and Travis Barker did.

Part of the comeback is also due to the influence of Lil Wayne. As a rapper, he’s on the list of the greatest of all time. But one of his most impactful statements came on his rock record Rebirth. The Complex article “Lil Wayne’s Worst Album Is Also His Most Influential” discusses how the album paved the way for newer hip-hop artists.

It mentions Lil Uzi Vert and Travis Scott being profoundly influenced by this record. The autotuned sing-song style of both artists can be directly traced back to Rebirth.

Plenty of rappers have openly expressed their rock influences, but it's been more pronounced in the last decade. Whether it is fashion or sound, the ideology…
